questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text.
Valentina Tereshkova was born in a village, in Central Russia on 6 March 1937. Her father was a tractor driver and her mother worked in a textile plant. At the age of eight she began her schooling but did not enjoy it much. She left the school within a few years. Afterwards she completed her education through distance learning. She became interested in parachuting from a young age, and trained in skydiving at the local Aeroclub, making her first jump at age 22 on 21 May 1959. It was her expertise in skydiving that led to her selection as a cosmonaut.After the flight of Yuri Gagarin, the first human being to travel to outer space in April 1961, the Soviet Union decided to send a woman in space. On 16 February 1962, "proletaria" Valentina Tereshkova was selected for this project from among more than four hundred applicants. Tereshkova had to undergo a series of training that included weightless flights, isolation tests, centrifuge tests, rocket theory, spacecraft engineering, 120 parachute jumps and pilot training in MiG-15UTI jet fighters. Since the successful launch of the spacecraft Vostok-5 on 14 June 1963, Tereshkova began preparing for her own flight. On the morning of 16 June 1963, Tereshkova and her. back-up cosmonaut Solovyova were dressed in space-suits and taken to the space shuttle launch pad by a bus. After completing her communication and life support checks, she was sealed inside Vostok-6. Finishing a two-
hour countdown, Vostok-6 launched faultlessly. Although Tereshkova experienced nausea and physical discomfort for much of the flight, she orbited the earth 48 times and spent almost three days in space. With a single flight, she logged more flight time than the combined times of all American astronauts who had flown before that date. Tereshkova also maintained a flight log and took photographs of the horizon, which were later used to identify aerosol layers within the atmosphere. Vostok-6 was the final Vostok flight and was launched two days after Vostok-5, which carried Valary Bykovsky into a similar orbit for five days, landing three hours after Tereshkova. The two vessels approached each other within 5 kilometers at one point, and from space Tereshkova communicated with Bykovsky and the Soviet leader Khrushchev by radio.

sub_questions.explanation: Valentina Tereshkova, born in 1937, grew up in Central Russia. She left school early but continued education through distance learning. Passionate about parachuting, she trained extensively and made her first jump at 22. Selected as a cosmonaut in 1962, she underwent rigorous training. On June 16, 1963, she boarded Vostok-6, becoming the first woman in space. Despite feeling discomfort, she orbited Earth 48 times in nearly three days, contributing valuable data. Her flight time surpassed combined American astronaut times. Tereshkova's achievements marked a significant milestone in space exploration.

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text :
The orphanage is high in the Carolina mountains. I was there in the autumn. T wanted quiet, isolation, to do some troublesome writing. I wanted mountain air to blow out the Malaria from too long, a time in the subtropics. I was home-sick too, for the flaming of Maples in October, and for corn shocks and pumpkins and black-walnut trees - ... I found them all living in a cabin that belonged to the orphanage, half a mile beyond the orphanage farm. When I took the cabin, i i i asked for a boy or man to come and chop wood for the fireplace ....... I looked up from my typewriter one late afternoon, a little startied. A boy stood at the door and my pointer dog. my companion, was at his side and had not barked to warn me. The boy was probably twelve years old, but under sized. He wore overalls and a torn shirt, and was barefooted. He said, "I can chop some wood today."

sub_questions.explanation: he narrator visits an orphanage in the Carolina mountains during autumn, seeking solitude, fresh air, and relief from past illness. Longing for the seasonal beauty of October, they stay in a remote cabin belonging to the orphanage. Wanting help with firewood, the narrator asks for assistance. One afternoon, a quiet, undersized twelve-year-old boy unexpectedly arrives at the door, offering to chop wood, surprising the narrator and their normally alert dog.

(a) After her wedding, Shilpi joined a local empowerment
(b) The group's activities include discussions on how to most effectively change behaviour related to
reproductive health as well as one-on-one counselling.
(c) The empowerment group is one of more than 10,000 groups supported by some local Non Government Organizations (NGOs) working all over Bangladesh.
(d) Marrying off daughters at an early age is a standard practice for many families living in rural Bangladesh.
(e) These trainings help adolescents say no to early marriage.
(f) During one of the group sessions, Shilpi came to understand the potentially harmful effects of early marriage and pregnancy.

sub_questions.explanation:
g)→(d)→(a)→(j)→(b) → (i)→(e)→(c)→(h)→(f)
Shilpi was only 15 years old when she married Rashid in 2008. Marrying off daughters at an early age is a standard practice for many families living in rural Bangladesh. After her wedding, Shilpi joined a local empowered group. The group provides adolescent girls with the tools needed to gradually change cultural practices, particularly those pertaining to early marriage and pregnancy. The group's activities include discussions on how to most effectively. change behaviour related to reproductive health as well as one-on-one counselling. It also offers peer-to-peer support and life skills training. These trainings help adolescents say no to early marriage. The empowerment group is one of more than 10,000 groups supported by some local Non Government Organizations (NGOs) working all over Bangladesh. These NGOs work through Canada's Adolescent Reproductive Health Project which also aims to increase access to quality health services for adolescents. During one of the group sessions, Shilpi came to understand the potentially harmful effects of early marriage and pregnancy.

questions.uddipok:
The following sentences are jumbled. Re-arrange them in proper sequence:
(i) Hojja became furious and decided to teach him a lesson.
(ii) Suddenly, he saw someone calling from below.
(iii) Hojja immediately replied, “why did you make me climb all the way down stairs to ask for money? Couldn't you see that I was working?"
(iv) When he came near, the man said that he was a beggar and wanted some money.
(v) One day, Nasiruddin Hojja was mending a hole on the roof of his two storeyed house.
(vi) The beggar was very surprised and asked why Hojja had made him climb the stairs to say he had no money.
(vii) When they both got to the rooftop, where he was previously working, Hojja turned towards the man and said, "Sorry, I have no money, so you have to leave."
(viii) He saw there was a man standing at the foot of the stairs and was asking him to get down and listen to him.
(ix) So, he told the man to climb the stairs with him.
(x) Being curious, he climbed down from the roof and went down the stairs.

sub_questions.explanation:
Here is the proper sequence of the sentences:
(v) One day, Nasiruddin Hojja was mending a hole on the roof of his two-storeyed house.
(ii) Suddenly, he saw someone calling from below.
(viii) He saw there was a man standing at the foot of the stairs and was asking him to get down and listen to him.
(x) Being curious, he climbed down from the roof and went down the stairs.
(iv) When he came near, the man said that he was a beggar and wanted some money.
(i) Hojja became furious and decided to teach him a lesson.
(ix) So, he told the man to climb the stairs with him.
(vii) When they both got to the rooftop, where he was previously working, Hojja turned towards the man and said, "Sorry, I have no money, so you have to leave."
(vi) The beggar was very surprised and asked why Hojja had made him climb the stairs to say he had no money.
(iii) Hojja immediately replied, “Why did you make me climb all the way down stairs to ask for money? Couldn't you see that I was working?"

questions.uddipok:
The graph below shows the importance and usage of English. Describe the graph in at least 80 words:
(By serial)
Usage of English in information technology 80%
Usage of English as the 1st language 33%
Used in various organizations 30%
Used in other purposes 50%
Using English as the 2nd language 58%

sub_questions.explanation: The given graph illustrates the importance and usage of English in various fields. According to the data, English is most widely used in information technology, with an 80% usage rate, highlighting its dominance in the tech industry. 58% of people use English as their second language, while only 33% use it as their first language, indicating that English is more commonly learned as a secondary language. Additionally, 30% of organizations use English in various official functions, and 50% of people use it for other purposes, showing its broad application beyond formal communication. The graph suggests that English is a crucial global language, particularly in technology, education, and professional sectors.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of a story. Complete it in your own words:
Urmi was an HSC examinee. After completing her HSC exam, she went to Dhaka to take admission test in Dhaka University, But she did not get chance in the university. Being frustrated, she returned…

sub_questions.explanation:
Urmi was an HSC examinee. After completing her HSC exam, she went to Dhaka to take admission test in Dhaka University, But she did not get chance in the university. Being frustrated, she returned home, the weight of disappointment heavy on her shoulders. Tears welled up in her eyes as familiar sights of her town greeted her - the bustling market, the rickety rickshaws honking their way through the streets, the comforting aroma of street food wafting through the air. Everything seemed the same, yet everything felt different.
Urmi locked herself in her room, the silence amplifying the hollowness within her. Her dream of studying at the prestigious Dhaka University felt like shattered glass. Her parents, though worried, offered quiet words of comfort. Her mother, ever the optimist, reminded her, "One closed door doesn't mean the end of the road, beta."
Days turned into weeks, and the initial sting of rejection began to dull. Urmi found solace in the company of her old friends. They too were navigating their own post-exam uncertainties, and their shared experiences offered a sense of camaraderie. One afternoon, while browsing the internet with a friend, Urmi stumbled upon a brochure for a renowned private university in her city. It offered a program in literature, her true passion, alongside a vibrant campus life.
A spark of hope ignited within her. Urmi researched the university, her heart pounding with a newfound excitement. The application process was swift, and to her immense joy, she received an acceptance letter. It wasn't Dhaka University, but it was an opportunity, a chance to pursue her dreams closer to home.
Stepping onto the bustling campus of her new university, Urmi took a deep breath. The disappointment of the past still lingered, but it was overshadowed by a sense of determination. She may not have achieved her initial goal, but she had found a new path, one that could lead her to a future filled with learning, growth, and maybe, just maybe, a career that would make her heart sing.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Sumon/Sumona and your friend is Anik/Anika. Now, write a letter to your friend expressing your sympathy for his/her suffering from COVID-19.

sub_questions.explanation:
56 RK Mission Road, Cumilla
5 June 2023
Dear Anik,
I have been informed by Reza that being infected with COVID-19, you are now hospitalized in Dhaka. This information was just like a bolt from the blue to me. I did not expect it as I knew that, you had always been very careful and cautious about maintaining safe distance and wearing mask. Anyway, "Prevention is better than cure" does not always work. Sometimes, many unexpected (অপ্রত্যাশিত) things happen in our life and we must remain ready to face and fight them out. COVID-19 is now a pandemic (অতিমারী/বৈশ্বিক মহামারি); anybody may be infected with COVID-19 any time and anywhere. So, there is nothing to be worried. Many COVID-19 patients are being dehospitalized everyday after full recovery. Have patience and follow your doctor's advice. You are a conscious person and I am sure you will maintain your quarantine (সঙ্গনিরোধ) period properly. By the grace of the Almighty, you will come round very soon. Don't lose your mental strength. Courage and mental strength play a vital role to cure a COVID-19 patient. You know vaccination programme is going on across the world including our country. So, after getting fully recovered, don't make delay in getting vaccinated.
Wishing your earliest recovery.
Your loving friend,
Sumon
